p: Vaccination has been described as one of the most successful public health interventions to date [ 12]. Our modern vaccinology era started when Edward Jenner, an English general practitioner, conducted the first scientific investigation on smallpox prevention in 1796 [ 13]. Since then, vaccinations have reduced disease, disability, and death from a variety of infectious diseases all over the world [ 12]. Despite this success, there is still a great need for new vaccines that can prevent and reduce the impact of outbreaks of both endemic infectious diseases and emerging infectious diseases [ 14]. In the case of EIDs, this is especially challenging due to the fact that the identity of the pathogen responsible for the disease, as well as the time and location of the next outbreak, cannot be accurately predicted using current means [ 15, 16].
